questions.text: At an urban PHC, ANM is given 1 vial of pentavalent vaccine, and 2 vials of MR vaccine. Both were already open before. Provided that all the cold chain requirements are still intact, will you use them or discard them? Mark accordingly.

options.label: A
options.text: Use both Pentavalent and MR open vials

options.label: C
options.text: Use Pentavalent and discard MR vial

options.label: D
options.text: Use MR and discard Pentavalent vial

questions.correct_answer: C. Use Pentavalent and discard MR vial
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Use Pentavalent and discard MR vial

Highyeild:

The Open Vial Policy (OVP) was introduced in India in 2013 for reducing both vaccine wastage as well as government healthcare costs for immunization, which was further revised in September 2015. Implementation of Open Vial Policy allows reuse of partially used multi dose vials of applicable vaccines under UIP in subsequent sessions (both fixed and outreach) up to four weeks (28 days) subject to meeting certain conditions and thus reduces vaccine wastage. Open Vial Policy is applicable on DPT, TT, Hepatitis B, Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV), Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) containing Pentavalent vaccine and injectable Inactivated Poliovirus Vaccine (IPV). Open Vial Policy does not apply to Measles, BCG and Japanese Encephalitis (JE) vaccines.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A. Use both Pentavalent and MR open vials - incorrect - we use Pentavalent and discard MR vial. Option B. Discard both - incorrect - we use Pentavalent and discard MR vial. Option D. Use MR and discard Pentavalent vial - incorrect - we use Pentavalent and discard MR vial.

Extraedge:

Discard vaccine vial in case any one of the following conditions is met: The Expiration date has passed. VVM reached/crossed discard point (for freeze dried vaccine, before reconstitution only) or vaccine vials without VVM or disfigured VVM. No label/partially torn label and/or writing on label not legible. Any vial thought to be exposed to non-sterile procedure for withdrawal. Open vials that have been under water or vials removed from a vaccine carrier that has water. If the vaccine vial is frozen or contains floccules or any foreign body. If there is breakage in the continuity of the vials (crack/leaks). If there is any reported AEFI following use of any of the vaccine vials, do not use it, and retain it safely. Inform Medical Officer and/or Supervisor.

questions.text: For the applied nutrition program, seeds and manure supply under school health services has been done by?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

UNICEF The applied nutrition program, seeds and manure supply is done by UNICEF.

Highyeild:

The Applied Nutrition Programme (ANP) was introduced in 1964 with the objectives of: a) promoting production of protective food such as vegetables and fruits ensuring their consumption by pregnant and nursing mothers and children. During 1973, it was extended to all the states of the country. The idea was to provide better seeds and encourage kitchen gardens, poultry farming, beehive keeping etc. India signed a master plan of operation with UNICEF and its sister agencies, WHO and FAO; UNICEF assisted ANP with equipment and supplies. GOBI-FFF: Growth monitoring, oral rehydration, breast-feeding and immunization: female education, family spacing and food supplementation (applied nutrition)are a selective package of World Health Organisation primary health care strategies recommended by UNICEF. The Strategy is also destined for working on nutrition relevant programmes, such as health, water and sanitation, education, protection and social policy, as well as the right to nutrition for every child.

The basic strategies for health promotion identified by WHO (in the Ottawa Charter) - Advocate (to boost the factors which encourage health), enable (allowing all people to achieve health equity) and mediate (through collaboration across all sectors). Option C . It is one of the largest and oldest humanitarian aid organizations focused on fighting global poverty. Option D . The UNDP develops solutions in three main areas- democratic governance and peace-building, sustainable development and climate and disaster resilience. By focusing its efforts on these three fundamental objectives, the UNDP takes a multidimensional approach to eliminate poverty at the source. To accomplish the MDGs and encourage global development, UNDP focuses on poverty reduction, HIV/AIDS, democratic governance, energy and environment, social development, and crisis prevention and recovery. UNDP also encourages the protection of human rights and the empowerment of women in all of its programs.

questions.text: Which of the following is true with respect to U-CHC norms requirement?

options.label: A
options.text: Where Sub District or District Hospital are not present

questions.explanation:
Solution:

100 Bedded in Metro Cities Population norms for urban health infrastructure.

Highyeild:

Community Health Centres - 2,50,000 population (5 Lakh for metros). Primary Health Centres - 50,000 population. Urban Community Health Centre (U-CHC) is set up as a referral facility for every 4-5 U-PHCs. The U-CHC caters to a population of 250000 to 5 Lakhs.

Extraedge:

In addition to primary health care facilities, it provides inpatient services, medical care, surgical facilities and institutional delivery facilities. It is a 30-50 bedded facility. For the metro cities, UCHCs may be established for every 5 lakh population with 100 beds. UCHCs can be established in areas even when sub districts or district hospitals are present.

questions.text: A cohort study is undertaken to study the association between green tea intake and diabetes mellitus. Relative Risk is found to be 0.85. Which of the following is correct regarding the association between green tea and diabetes mellitus?

options.label: A
options.text: Green Tea Consumption increases the risk of DM

options.label: B
options.text: Green Tea Consumption decreases the risk of DM

options.label: C
options.text: Green Tea Consumption has no effect on DM

questions.correct_answer: B. Green Tea Consumption decreases the risk of DM
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Green Tea Consumption decreases the risk of DM In the given MCQ since odds ratio is 0.85, green tea consumption is a protective factor for DM.

Highyeild:

The relative risk is the measure of association for a cohort study. A relative risk of: (0 or close to 1.0) means the risk of disease is similar in the exposed and unexposed group and exposure is not associated with disease. Greater than 1.0 means the risk of disease is greater in the exposed than the unexposed group and the exposure could be a risk factor for the disease. Less than 1.0 means the risk of disease is less in the exposed group than the unexposed group and the exposure could be a protective factor.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Options A, C and D are false

questions.text: A male patient diagnosed with tuberculosis took complete treatment. The first sputum examination was done after the completion of the intensive and the continuation phases. It was found to be negative. What is the status of the patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cured As sputum examination is negative after completion of treatment.

Highyeild:

New patients have never been treated for TB or have taken anti-TB drugs for less than 1 month. Previously treated patients have received 1 month or more of anti-TB drugs in the past. Other previously treated patients are those who have previously been treated for TB but whose outcome after their most recent course of treatment is unknown or undocumented. Patients with unknown previous TB treatment history do not fit into any of the categories listed above. New and relapse cases of TB are incident TB cases. The same has been stated in Guidance for National Tuberculosis Programmes on the Management of Tuberculosis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Relapse patients have previously been treated for TB, were declared cured or treatment completed at the end of their most recent course of treatment, and are now diagnosed with a recurrent episode of TB (either a true relapse or a new episode of TB caused by reinfection). Option D - Treatment after failure patients are those who have previously been treated for TB and whose treatment failed at the end of their most recent course of treatment. Option C - Treatment after loss to follow-up patients have previously been treated for TB and were declared lost to follow-up at the end of their most recent course of treatment. (These were previously known as treatment after default patients.)

questions.text: Lifespan of Japanese women is 84.3 years. As Japanese have the longest life expectancy, their life expectancy statistics are used as a standard for measuring disease burden in?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Disability adjusted Life Expectancy Disability adjusted Life Expectancy is used as a standard for disease burden.

Highyeild:

QALYs (Quality-Adjusted Life Year) and DALYs (Disability-Adjusted Life Year) are common terms used within this framework. QALYs are a measure of years lived in perfect health gained whereas DALYs are a measure of years in perfect health lost. They are the most frequently cited metrics for risk-benefit assessment. The overall burden of disease is assessed using the disability-adjusted life year (DALY), a time-based measure that combines years of life lost due to premature mortality (YLLs) and years of life lost due to time lived in states of less than full health, or years of healthy life lost due to disability (YLDs). One DALY represents the loss of the equivalent of one year of full health. Using DALYs, the burden of diseases that cause premature death but little disability (such as drowning or measles) can be compared to that of diseases that do not cause death but do cause disability (such as cataract causing blindness).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Health-adjusted life years (HALYs) are population health measures permitting morbidity and mortality to be simultaneously described within a single number. They are useful for overall estimates of burden of disease, comparisons of the relative impact of specific illnesses and conditions on communities, and in economic analyses. Option B - Quality-adjusted life years (QALYs) and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) are types of HALYs whose original purposes are at variance.

questions.text: Many children from a particular community coming to a hospital were detected to have acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). It was assumed that it is due to the presence of cytotoxic waste in the water of that community. If a case-control study has to be done to find whether the chemical and ALL are associated, what will be taken as the control?

options.label: A
options.text: Children from the area were exposed, but unaffected with the disease

options.label: B
options.text: Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease

options.label: C
options.text: Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease

options.label: D
options.text: All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status

questions.correct_answer: C. Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Children coming to your OPD, who do not have the disease.

Highyeild:

Typical sources for cases include: Patient rosters at medical facilities Death certificates Disease registries Cross-sectional surveys The comparison group (controls) should be representative of the source population that produced the cases. The controls must be sampled in a way that is independent of the exposure, meaning that their selection should not be more (or less) likely if they have the exposure of interest. They must be as alike as possible, except for the fact that they do not have the disease or the risk factor that is being tested/studied.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Children from the area exposed, but unaffected with the disease - Not coming to hospital - so not included in control either. Option B - Children from the area not exposed and affected with the disease - affected children are never taken as controls. Option D - All children with ALL irrespective of exposure status - not the correct option.

questions.text: Most logical and cost-effective approach to controlling rabies in urban populations is?

options.label: A
options.text: Test all the dogs for rabies

options.label: B
options.text: Remove stray dogs and vaccinating the dog population

options.label: C
options.text: Administer rabies vaccine to entire human population

questions.correct_answer: B. Remove stray dogs and vaccinating the dog population
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Remove stray dogs and vaccinating the dog population

Highyeild:

Rabies is a highly fatal viral disease caused by lyssavirus type 1 , affecting the central nervous system. Dogs are considered the major source of rabies infection. Thus, immunization of dogs at the age of 3-4 months and booster doses at regular intervals is recommended to control rabies.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Testing all dogs for rabies or administering a rabies vaccine to the entire human population would be extremely costly and thus not an efficient measure. Option C: Administer rabies vaccine to the entire human population - this is neither suitable nor a feasible option. Option D: Health education might serve as a preliminary measure of awareness and prevention, but there can still be cases of rabid dog bite.

Extraedge:

The type of vaccines used are: BPL inactivated nervous tissue vaccine – it is a single dose vaccine. Booster is advised after 6 months and subsequently every year. Modified live virus vaccine – it is also a single dose vaccine and a booster is given every 3 years.
